content: It looks like docs#Antisymm is in Type while it should be in Prop. Also, do you use it in core? It looks like most of the other similar classes from Lean 3 were deleted. Mathlib has a copy of the old typeclasses as docs#IsAntisymm, docs#IsEquiv etc.
Regarding naming, if there is consensus that these typeclasses should all have Is in their name, I am happy to replace the core Antisymm with IsAntisymm (or to review a PR doing so.)
I don't know if there is a consensus.

When reviewing a PR adding things like abundant numbers I suggested they be called IsAbundant but then I realised that we had Prime and Perfect. I'd definitely be in favour of enforcing Is for Props, I think it makes for better understanding (for example it helps when trying to figure out how to make things like integral domains)
OTOH, there was a migration from IsLawful* to Lawful*.
Note that Trans is not in Prop (intentionally, I think).
Yes, we have non-Prop instances for Trans like docs#Equiv.instTrans. This way we can use calc with Equivs.
There's some previous discussion in this thread and in lean4#3195 classes like IsAssociative were renamed to Associative.

Does this mean you would want IsFinite rather than Finite @Kevin Buzzard? I'd like to avoid that.

If a word is clearly an adjective, I think there's no need for Is. Something like Prime is confusing since it's both a noun and an adjective, and you can use Is to "predicativize" it.

Yeah I personally would like a hard and fast rule where all predicates are Is and all non-predicates are not. But I'm well aware that others have different views, for example Yael has argued that Is when it's not grammatically necessary is making declarations have longer names.
An advantage of having a simple rule is that it would be easy to enforce with a linter.
The currently-non-existing linter could of course have a list of exceptions, but then the extra burden of expanding the list of exceptions may make the rule end up having few exceptions organically.
In fact, I find all these Type vs Prop distinctions very error-prone and hard to notice.
